title: South Australian mother begs to be freed from jail after kidnapping her kids from state care
text:
A pregnant mother-of-seven arrested for kidnapping two of her children from state care has begged to be released from jail.

The mother, 23, with her partner abducted their two sons aged three and six during a visit to a South Australian Child Protection Department office in October last year.

The father, 34, pretended he was taking the boys to the bathroom before taking them and going on the run.

The children were found by police a day later, after they were spotted at a petrol station in Broken Hill - and were taken into custody.

The mother, 23, (pictured) with her partner took their two sons aged three and six during a visit to a South Australian Child Protection Department office during October last year

The mother and father were extradited in New South Wales in January but allegedly cut off their electronic monitoring bracelets and had gone on the run, The Advertiser reported.

The couple were arrested in June in Queensland and pleaded guilty to two aggravated counts each of sending or taking a child out of jurisdiction.

The father's lawyer, Danni Stephens told the District Court on Monday that the eldest boy had been taken to hospital in March last year with 'unexplained injuries' under the state's care.

The father claimed he was told that he had been 'assaulted and locked in a room'.

He also claimed his youngest son had a black eye.

Ms Stephens said the man had planned to take the children and was acting as a 'distraught father'.

The court heard the couple had been evicted from their home and had planned to take their children to Queensland.

The mother's lawyer, Peter Hill, told the court the incident was the 'actions of desperate parents' and she was 'genuinely remorseful' for what she had done.

She is currently 20 weeks pregnant with her eight child.

The pair will be sentenced next month.
